did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

did.abstract: The Baron Papers comprise the personal, professional, and research material of Salo Baron and occupy approximately 398 linear feet. As of July 1992 the papers total 714 boxes and are arranged in 11 series, including correspondence, personal/biographical, archival materials, subject, manuscripts, notecards, pamphlets, reprints, and books, manuscripts (other authors), notes, photo and audio-visual.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers. M0580. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Acquired from Salo W. Baron, 1986 and 1990.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Salo Wittmayer Baron was instrumental in establishing Jewish Studies as an academic discipline in the United States. An extraordinarily prolific historian, Baron also played an exceptional role in American Jewish organizational life. Baron was born in 1895 in Tarnow, now in Poland but then part of Austrian Galicia. His parents, Elias Baron and Minna Wittmayer Baron, were orthodox Jews, and Elias Baron was a banker and Jewish community leader. Salo Baron had two sisters: Gisa (1892-1943) and Tanya (Tania, "Toni") (1898-?). Both Gisa and the parents died in the Holocaust in 1943. Studying at the University of Vienna, Baron earned doctorates in history (1917), political science (1922), and law (1923). Baron also completed a rabbinical degree from the Jewish Theological Seminary in Vienna in 1920. After teaching at the Juedisches Paedagogium in Vienna from 1919 to 1926, Baron left for the United States, where he joined the faculty of the Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. Baron was offered the newly-created Miller Chair of Jewish History, Literature, and Institutions in 1930 by Columbia University, where he remained for the rest of his career (emeritus after 1963). In 1936 Baron and Morris R. Cohen founded the Conference on Jewish Relations (later called the Conference on Jewish Social Studies), which publishes the journal Jewish Social Studies. The author of more than a dozen monographs and over 500 articles on Jewish history, Baron had an extraordinary range and scope. He was at home in ancient, medieval, and modern history and could read twenty languages. His magnum opus was A Social and Religious History of the Jews, which filled 18 volumes. Baron saw his scholarship as a corrective to what he termed "the lachrymose conception of Jewish history." His work focused on the social history and cultural accomplishments of the Jews rather than on suffering and pogroms. Baron also sought to reintegrate religious experience into the historical fabric of Jewish life. Beginning with his work on the Permanent Minorities Commission of the League of Nations in 1925, Baron served on various international committees during his long career. He founded and directed Jewish Cultural Reconstruction, an organization dedicated to identifying and reclaiming Jewish cultural patrimony plundered by the Nazis. At the invitation of Ben Gurion, Baron testified at the Eichmann trial in 1961. In addition, Baron directed or served as trustee for several academic institutions and organizations in this country and in Israel.

scopecontent.p: Measuring 70 linear feet, the correspondence of Salo W. Baron has an extraordinary range and depth. Baron's first letters are from before the First World War, and he was an energetic correspondent until his death in 1989. The scope of the correspondence is quite broad, covering personal, professional, and financial matters. Because Baron generally kept copies of his outgoing correspondence, all of these materials are very rich. Although the correspondence is largely in English, there are many letters in Hebrew and German as well as several in Polish, French, Spanish, Portuguese, and Italian. The overview on page 12 summarizes the general organization of the correspondence, which is described in more detail below.

Although Baron filed most of his correspondence separately, some letters escaped this system. In sorting through the Baron Papers as a whole, most of the correspondence, filed or not, was removed. Nevertheless some letters were left in other series of the collection (see especially the manuscripts and subject series) because of the information they provided on the specific materials they accompanied. In the correspondence series, some noncorrespondence materials (such as financial reports) are included, mainly because these items were originally filed with the correspondence. To the greatest degree possible Baron's letters have been kept in their original order. Baron maintained two residences, one in Canaan, Connecticut and the other in New York City, and thus two separate files of letters. This division has been preserved here, so that the first part of the correspondence is labelled as the Canaan files and the second as the New York files. Divided into these two parts, the correspondence is then organized more or less chronologically. Within these chronological divisions, the letters are generally arranged alphabetically by the correspondent's name or institutional affiliation. The title of each folder is taken directly from Baron's own filing system in the vast majority of cases. This means that the dates given in the folder title are often inaccurate. The range of dates provided in the "Years" column of the user's guide reflects the folder contents much more accurately. When only incoming or outgoing correspondence is contained in a folder, this is generally noted in the user's guide; when both incoming and outgoing letters are included, no special note is made. The letters in Hebrew, which are scattered throughout the correspondence, pose special difficulties. Hebrew letters that are filed by correspondent in their own folders are included in the user's guide. However, other letters are not listed because the collection's processors cannot read Hebrew. Still, some of these correspondents maynonetheless be included in the user's guide because Baron often answered his Hebrew correspondence in English, since it was easier to dictate. In the correspondence there are often small white pieces of paper with lists of names on them. It seems that these were made by Baron to show which items he had removed for use in writing his autobiography. Materials pertaining to this autobiography can be found in several series, including the Personal/Biographical Series and the Manuscript Series. Baron's professional correspondence also includes many files that contain non-correspondence items such as reports, bills, budgets, grant applications, articles, and newspaper clippings. In going through the Baron Papers, the processors tried to sort out those files that were primarily correspondence and leave the others. Because of the size of the collection and the complexity of the materials, this division is somewhat arbitrary. Researchers may want to look at the subject series if they are interested in particular organizations with which Baron was involved. In the professional correspondence, the processors have tried to follow Baron's own filing system, which was a mixture of classification by subject and by date. Professional correspondence left unordered by Baron has been inserted at the closest and most logical point possible. Papers of Jeannette Baron, Baron's wife, are included here because her professional life was virtually inseparable from Baron's.

In general this division contains correspondence with Baron's daughters, Tobey Baron Gitelle and Shoshana Baron Tancer, as well as with other relatives and family friends. Also included here are letters marking important life events, such as daughters' weddings, Baron's 60th, 70th, and 90th birthdays, his 50th wedding anniversary, and his wife's sickness and death. Baron's personal and professional lives were very much intertwined; many of his closest friends were colleagues. Thus it is sometimes difficult to make the distinction between "personal" and "professional" correspondence. Some personal correspondence is included with the professional correspondence, and some professional letters can be found with more personal ones.

The Personal/Biographical Series is made up of items that relate direcly to Baron's own experience and that did not fit into the other series because of their personal or peripheral nature. Among the contents of the series are: Gymnasium certificates; university diplomas; awards; newspaper clippings about Baron; reviews of Baron's books; announcements of lectures and speeches by Baron; legal and financial documents; address books; and calendars. Things of a similar nature pertaining to Baron's wife and daughters are also included. The title of this series may be a bit misleading since Baron's autobiography is grouped with the manuscript series. Moreover, the division between this series and others is not absolute. Newspaper clippings and reviews of Baron's books can also be found in the subject series.

scopecontent.p: This series contains many of the research materials that Baron gathered in the course of his work. The large majority of these are transcripts, photocopies, and microfilms of archival materials. Some of these copies may be especially valuable in the case of archives that were damaged in World War II. Other items in the series are notes from printed sources, handwritten notes, original archival documents (particularly from Romania), and historical newspaper clippings. Copies of the items in this series may not be available from Stanford because the copyright may still be held by the original archive.

scopecontent.p: These boxes comprise a catch-all series, encompassing many materials that did not fit into more clear-cut series such as Correspondence or Manuscripts. Most of this series is made up of materials from the various organizations that Baron worked with, among them the Conference on Jewish Social Studies, Jewish Cultural Reconstruction, and Hebrew University. This series also contains things from his activities at Columbia Univesity: as professor of history and as head of the Center for Israeli and Jewish Studies. Finally this series has things like his class and public lectures (often fully written out), gradebooks, and student papers.

scopecontent.p: This series contains everything from first drafts of books and articles to the galley proofs. Only papers by Salo or Jeannette Baron were included here. The first 83 boxes of this series contain different manuscript versions of Baron`s 17-volume opus A Social and Religious History of the Jews; other major book manuscripts follow. A couple of books are collections of articles edited by Baron; in these cases, the contributions of other authors were included. The last 40 boxes contain drafts of published and unpublished articles and reviews by Baron as well as lectures. Whenever possible, title and date have been identified; due to the high number of these short publications, they are in no thematical or chronological order. Offprints and reprints (even 3 bound collections of reprints, boxes 403-405) of many articles are also included, as well as some of Baron's early handwritten essays (box 387), his autobiography (boxes 379-380), a bound copy of his dissertation submitted in 1917 (box 408), and his testimonyto the Eichmann trial (box 406). Next to English, the major languages are German and Hebrew. Unfortunately, the title of the texts in Hebrew could not be identified; they are listed simply as "Article/Mss in Hebrew." The first folder of this series (box 252) contains a bibliography of Baron's works (1912-75) and table contents of the books included in this series in order to facilitate access to the collection. Notes to A Social and Religious History of the Jews are also included in box no. 687 of the Notes Series (see p. 167 of the guide).

scopecontent.p: This series contains bibliographical index cards and handwritten notecards; they are preserved in 3x5x12 inch boxes. The original order of the drawers containing these index- and notecards corresponded apparently to Baron's major works, especially his Social and Religious History of the Jews (17 vols., 81 chapters). Unfortunately, this order could not be reconstructed entirely. Approximately the first 100 boxes of this series are divided in alphabetically organized sub-series of bibliographical information. The single works these sub-series belong to were not always identifiable. Boxes no. 507-509 and no. 568 contain notes in Hebrew. The last four boxes of this series contain addresses and invitation cards.

did.unittitle: Series 7. Pamphlets, Reprints and Books Series

scopecontent.p: This series consists of miscellaneous items (mostly printed materials) collected by Baron such as: contemporary and historical pamphlets, offprints and photocopies of articles, newspapers (such as the Detroit Jewish Chronicle*), manuscript documents (box 639), bibliographies and book catalogues, travel guides, and books.

scopecontent.p: This group is made up of unpublished materials by Baron's students, friends, and colleagues, who frequently sent him their work-in-progress for his comments. The series consists mostly of typescripts of books, articles, and conference papers; galley proofs, photocopies of articles, student papers, M.A. and Ph.D. theses are also included. The boxes no. 649, 651 (folder 1, 8-10), 652, 653, 654 (folder 1-7), 656 (folder 14, 15), 658, 659, 660 (folder 1-4), 669 (folder 15-18), 673 (folder 1-6), 674 (folder 8-14), 675 (folder 4-6) contain contributions by various authors to the series History of the Scientific and Cultural Development of Mankind.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of mostly handwritten, miscellaneous notes by Salo Wittmayer Baron; only a few of these manuscript fragments could be identified; for example, the boxes no. 686 and 687 contain, among other things, handwritten notes to A Social and Religious History of the Jews. The papers grouped together as "Miscellaneous Notes" are unidentified items the original order of which had been preserved. Some of those notes are in Hebrew Language.

did.unittitle: A Social and Religious History of the Jews; chapter XLVI; notes 1-17; original ms; pp. 847-861; notes 1-17; first carbon; pp. 1037-1053

scopecontent.p: The photos are largely of Baron and his family. There are a few pictures of contemporary historical events, probably collected for Baron's own research. The materials are in a prelimiary order, but no overview has been drawn up yet.

scopecontent.p: This series contains mostly reel-to-reel tapes of Baron's lectures and speeches, as well as some audiotapes, videotapes and records. There is at least one videotaped interview of Baron by Zvi Ankori, a former student, in 1987.
